Highly active and selective binary catalyst system for the coupling reaction of CO2 and hydrous epoxides Ren-Jian Wei Xing-Hong Zhang ⁎ Bin-Yang Du Zhi-Qiang Fan Guo-Rong Qi MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization, Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China MOE Key Laboratory of Macromolecular Synthesis and Functionalization Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 571 87953732; fax: +86 571 87953732. Graphical abstract Although most of the zinc-containing catalysts show excellent catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide (CO2) with epoxides, generally, trace amounts of water in the reaction systems could cause a significant decrease of the catalytic activity. In this work, a nanoporous zinc-cobalt double metal cyanide complex (Zn–CoIII DMCC) with high surface area was synthesized via a modified hydrothermal process using tri-block copolymer EO20PO70EO20 (P123) as the template. When cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was used as the co-catalyst, the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system could effectively catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 with hydrous propylene oxide (PO), producing propylene carbonate (PC) with nearly 100% productivity and 100% selectivity. This binary catalyst system could also catalyze the coupling reaction of other commercial epoxides and CO2 without using any solvents with nearly 100% productivity and 100% selectivity. With such new catalyst system, hundreds of ppm water in the reaction system will no longer be the matter. Keywords Carbon dioxide Epoxides Coupling reaction Double metal cyanide complex 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide is an important C1 feedstock because it is nontoxic, nonflammable, abundant and economical. The chemical fixation of CO2 into valuable organic chemicals has attracted much attention for the goals of environmental protection and sustainable development. The coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates is considered to be one of the promising routes for CO2 utilization [1,2]. Cyclic carbonates can be used as low-toxic aprotic polar solvents, monomers for producing polycarbonates, pharmaceutical chemical intermediates, and many biomedical applications [3]. Numerous catalysts with significant advances have been discovered for CO2-epoxides coupling reaction in recent decades. Heterogeneous catalysts such as metal oxides [4–6], zeolite and its supported catalysts [7–10] were utilized to catalyze CO2-epoxides coupling reaction. Although these catalysts were commonly easy to be separated from the products and found to be reusable up to several runs, their catalytic activities were rather low. Homogeneous catalysts such as amines and phosphines [11,12], alkali metal halides [13], metal-salen complexes [14,15], metal porphyrins [16,17], and transition metal complexes [18–20] were also extensively investigated. However, most of them suffered from low catalytic activity, low catalyst stability, air/water sensitivity and the needs of co-solvents. The zinc halide salts with organic salts as co-catalysts such as ZnBr2/PPh4PI [19] were highly active (the maximum TON: 6272, mol PO/mol Zn) and selective (>99%) for the coupling reaction of CO2-propylene oxide (PO). However, propylene carbonate (PC) productivity and selectivity of this catalyst system were strongly influenced by the trace water in the system. For example, the PO conversion decreased sharply from 89.6% to 8.1% with the presence of trace water, i.e. the molar ratio of 0.1 for H2O/ZnBr2. The complete removal of trace water from hydrophilic epoxides is clearly difficult and energy-consuming. It would be much better if commercial epoxides, which generally contain several hundreds of ppm water, could be directly used. Therefore, developing a water-endurable catalyst for the coupling reaction of CO2-propylene oxide (PO) will be significant and promising to the field because most of catalysts reported showed decrease in activity with the presence of trace water. Fortunately, we have previously found that zinc–cobalt (III) double metal cyanide complex (Zn–CoIII DMCC) could improve the production of PC with the addition of a small amount of water during PO-CO2 copolymerization [21], which suggested that such Zn–CoIII DMCC catalysts were stable in the presence of trace water and would be good candidates for the coupling reaction of CO2 with hydrous epoxides. A typical formula of DMCC catalyst is MII u [M(CN) n ] v ·xMIIX w ·yL·zH2O (MII =Zn2+, Fe2+, Ni2+, Co2+ etc.; M=Co2+, Co3+, Fe2+, Fe3+, etc.; X=Cl−, Br−, I− and OAc−, etc.; L is an electron-donating complex agent) [21–24]. For all of the reported DMCCs, Zn–CoIII DMCC exhibited the most excellent catalytic performance. DMCC catalyst was initially used as a high-efficiency catalyst for ring-opening polymerization (ROP) of epoxides [25–27], and later developed to be an active and selective catalyst for CO2-epoxides copolymerization [21,24]. Very recently, Zn–CoIII DMCC was also utilized for the copolymerization of CS2/epoxides [28], cyclic anhydrides/epoxides [29], as well as CO2/cyclic anhydrides/epoxides terpolymerization [30] with satisfied catalytic activities. Generally, cyclic carbonate would be produced if relative high reaction temperature was applied for the copolymerization of CO2-epoxides catalyzed by sole Zn–CoIII DMCC [21]. This intrigued us to develop a new Zn–CoIII DMCC system for the PC production from CO2-hydrous epoxide coupling reaction. A novel highly active binary catalyst system with a nanoporous zinc–cobalt double metal cyanide complex (Zn–CoIII DMCC) as the main catalyst and quaternary ammonium salts as the co-catalyst was successfully developed in the present work, which could catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 with commercial hydrous epoxides to afford cyclic carbonates with nearly 100% productivity and 100% selectivity under moderate conditions (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials K3Co(CN)6 (Yixing City Lianyang Chemical Co., Ltd, China, 99%) was recrystallized in de-ionized water before use. ZnCl2 and tert-BuOH were analytical grade and used without further purification. Propylene oxide (>99%) was reagent grade and used without purification. Carbon dioxide with 99.995% purity was used as received. Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), dodecyltrimethylammonum bromide (C10H21(CH3)3NBr), decyltrimethylammonium bromide (C12H25(CH3)3NBr), tetraethylammonium bromide, tetrabutylammonium bromide, tetrabutylammonium chloride, tetrabutylammonium iodide were all analytical grade and used without further purification. Styrene oxide, allyl glycidyl ether, epichlorohydrin, 4-tert-butylphenyl glycidyl ether were industrial grade and used as received. Pluronic copolymer P123 (EO20PO70EO20) was kindly provided by BASF SE and used directly. 2.2 Synthesis of nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC The given amounts of ZnCl2 (8.0g) were dissolved in 20ml de-ionized water. 1.8gK3Co(CN)6 and 1.5g P123 were dissolved in 20ml de-ionized water. The mixture solution of K3Co(CN)6 and P123 was then drop-wisely added into ZnCl2 solution at 30°C for 30min under vigorous mechanical stirring (1000rpm). Afterward, the reaction solution was heated to 75°C and greatly agitated for 3h, forming a uniform white suspension. This suspension was kept at the elevated temperature of 95–100°C for 24h under N2 atmosphere. The white precipitates were then separated by pressure filtration, and washed by de-ionized water for at least three times. The obtained semi-solid was then re-dispersed in tert-BuOH with magnetic stirring at 30°C for another 24h. Finally, the precipitates were isolated by pressure filtration, washed by tert-BuOH for several times at 30°C, and dried under vacuum at 100°C for 24h until a constant weight (loose powder) was obtained. Elemental analysis result (wt%): Co: 12.73, Zn: 28.01; C: 30.56; N: 15.23; Cl: 5.07; H: 3.12. 2.3 Coupling reaction of CO2-epoxides The general process of CO2-PO coupling reaction was given as following: a 100ml autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer was pre-dried under vacuum at 80°C for 2h. Zn–CoIII DMCC (10mg) and appropriate amounts of quaternary ammonium salts were transferred into the autoclave, which was then dried for another 2h. After the autoclave was cooled down to 25°C, PO (30ml) was injected into the autoclave using a syringe under negative pressure. The reactor was then heated and pressured to the desired temperature and CO2 pressure under vigorous stirring (500rpm). After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled with ice-water bath and the pressure was vented. A small amount of sample was removed for 1H NMR measurement. The crude products were then transferred to a round-bottomed flask and dried under reduced pressure. Pure propylene carbonate (PC, 4-methyl-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one) was obtained. 1H NMR (CDCl3, TMS, 400MHz): δ =1.5 (d, 3H), 4.0 (t, 1H), 4.5 (t, 1H), and 4.9–5.1 (m, 1H). The reusability of the Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst was tested as follows: after the PO-CO2 coupling reaction, the crude product was centrifuged at 15,000rpm, and the non-solvable catalysts were deposited at the bottom of centrifuge tube. The supernatant liquid was then separated, and the remained catalyst was collected. The collected catalyst was used for the next run in the same autoclave under the same reaction condition as that of the first run. The catalysts were recycled for four runs. The coupling reactions of CO2 with other commercial epoxides such as styrene oxide, allyl glycidyl ether, epichlorohydrin, 4-tert-butylphenyl glycidyl ether with CO2 were performed using the similar procedure described above. The 1H NMR results of the corresponding cyclic carbonates were listed below: 4-Phenyl-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one: 1H NMR (CDCl3, TMS, 400MHz): δ (ppm)=4.35 (t, 1H), 4.81 (t, 1H), 5.69 (t, 1H), 7.38–7.43(m, 5H). 4-(Allyloxymethyl)-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one: 1H NMR (CDCl3, TMS, 400MHz): δ (ppm)=3.61–3.72 (m, 2H), 4.07(m, 2H), 4.41 (t, 1H), 4.52 (t, 1H), 4.84 (t, 1H), 5.25(m, 2H), 5.87(m, 1H). 4-(Chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one: 1H NMR (CDCl3, TMS, 400MHz): δ (ppm)=3.72–3.83(m, 2H), 4.43 (t, 1H), 4.61 (t, 1H), 4.99 (t, 1H). 4-((4-tert-butylphenoxy)methyl)-1, 3-dioxolan-2-one: 1H NMR (CDCl3, TMS, 400MHz): δ (ppm)=1.30(s, 9H), 4.14(m, 1H), 4.24(m, 1H), 4.53(m, 1H), 4.60(m, 1H), 5.01(m, 1H), 6.86 (d, 2H), 7.34 (t, 2H). 2.4 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to characterize the morphology of the Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst, respectively. The SEM observation was performed on a JEOL JSM 840A SEM under vacuum after the sample was sputter-coated with gold at 10mA for 1min. The TEM observation was performed on a JEOL JEM-1230 TEM with an acceleration voltage of 80kV. The specific surface area was determined from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm (at liquid nitrogen temperature) according to the BET method by using a Quantachrome automated gas sorption system (AUTOSORB-1-C). The pore size distribution was calculated by analyzing the adsorption/desorption branches of the isotherm using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment was carried out on an RBD PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin–Elmer) with Mg Kα radiation (hv =1253.6eV). 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Advance DMX 400-MHz spectrometer by using TMS as the internal reference and CDCl3 as the solvent. Water content in PO was determined by using a MaxTitra20Q moisture meter (Shanghai Tianmei Scientific Instruments Co., Ltd. China) according to the Coulometric method. GC–MS analysis was carried out on a Thermo Finnigan ThermoQuest (San Jose, CA, USA) gas chromatograph equipped with a split/splitless injector and coupled with a mass detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and morphology of nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC A nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC was successfully prepared in water by a modified hydrothermal process with tri-block copolymer EO20PO70EO20 (P123) as the template (see Section 2). P123 could form spherical micelles with diameters of tens nanometres in aqueous solution [22,31]. Such P123 spherical micelles led to the formation of nanopores in the resultant Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst and hence the increase of surface area of Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst. Note that, water/tert-BuOH mixture could not be used because P123 could completely dissolve into tert-BuOH. However, tert-BuOH was used in the last slurry step in order to increase the activity of the final catalyst and completely remove P123. The SEM and TEM images show that the obtained Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst had spherical shape with average diameter of ∼50nm and partial aggregation (Fig. 1a and b). Fig. 1c shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm of the obtained Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst, which could be attributed to the typical type IV isotherm. The pore size distribution was rather broad ranging from several nm to ∼100nm as shown in the inset of Fig. 1c, suggesting that the pores were in disorder. The calculated BET surface area of the obtained Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst was 580m2/g. To the best of our knowledge, this was the first example of Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst with nanopores and a high surface area. Furthermore, the hydrothermal process at 95–100°C might contribute to the formation of the nanostructure because the control catalyst synthesized without hydrothermal process congregated and showed very low surface area (∼40m2/g). Fig. 2 shows X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) of the obtained Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst. The binding energy of Zn 2p3 in Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst was 1022.5eV and lower than that of pure ZnCl2 (the 2p3 XPS line at 1023.7eV). This shift could be attributed to the substitution of Cl for CN ligands and the coordination of tert-BuOH to the unsaturated Zn metal centers. Furthermore, the peak assigned to Co 2p3/2 shifted from 781.0eV for K3Co(CN)6 [22] to 782.0eV for the catalyst, indicating the change of microenvironments for the corresponding Co metal elements due to the generated Zn2+–CN–Co3+ complexes [32], as shown in Fig. 1d. Structurally, it was a three-dimensional backbone in which zinc and cobalt atoms were linked by cyanide bridges [28,30,32]. The local initiating site of Zn–CoIII DMCC has been proved to be zinc-hydroxyl (ZnOH) bond on its surface in our recent works [21,24]. Therefore, the Zn–CoIII DMCC with high surface area can accommodate more initiating sites than the unmodified one. The Zn–CoIII DMCC with nanopores obtained here indeed exhibited excellent activity for the coupling reaction of hydrous PO with CO2 by using quaternary ammonium salts as co-catalysts (see below). 3.2 Catalytic performances of Zn–CoIII DMCC with various quaternary ammonium salts It was well known that the quaternary ammonium salts could catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2-PO with 100% PC selectivity although they suffered from very low catalytic activity at the same time [33]. Several quaternary ammonium salts were thus selected as co-catalysts of Zn–CoIII DMCC for the coupling reaction of CO2-PO. Initially, the molar ratio of co-catalysts to zinc of Zn–CoIII DMCC was set to 0.65. As expected, the addition of small amounts of alkyl quaternary ammonium salts improved the productivity and selectivity of PC, as seen from the entries of 1, 3, 5–9 in Table 1 (Note that the calculation of PC selectivity was given in the caption of Fig. 3 ). The results indicated that the quaternary ammonium salts with Brˉ were better than those with Clˉ and Iˉ for improving the productivity and selectivity of PC (entries 1, 3 and 5 in Table 1). It was thought that Brˉ has a comprehensive strong leaving and nucleophilic abilities, which are favorable for PO activation [34]. Moreover, the use of more quaternary ammonium salts led to 100% selectivity of PC (entries 2 and 4, Table 1). The data of Table 1 also indicated that the quaternary ammonium salts with long alkyl chain showed relatively high TON in the order of C16H33(CH3)3 >C12H25(CH3)3 >C10H21(CH3)3 (entries 6–8, Table 1), which was consistent with the previous report [35]. The bigger cations in quaternary ammonium salts might be helpful for enhancing the leaving ability of Brˉ. A control experiment for CO2-PO coupling reaction was also carried out at a low catalyst concentration (10mg catalyst for 30ml PO, entry 2 in Table 1) and a low CO2 pressure (0.4MPa) for 2h. The resulting TON could be even up to 1990, which were about twice of the reported TON (958) by using a non-porous Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst [35]. A traditional Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst [32], which exhibited a non-porous structure and a low surface area of 230m2/g, was also tested for the PO-CO2 coupling reaction under the same condition as that of entry 8 of Table 1. A low TON of 595 was obtained. These results suggested that the nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst with high surface area would improve the catalytic activity for the PO-CO2 coupling reaction. 3.3 The effects of reaction parameters on the CO2-PO coupling reaction From the above results, cetyltrimethyl-ammonium bromide (CTAB) was then chosen as the optimum co-catalyst for Zn–CoIII DMCC. This binary catalyst system was employed to catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 with reagent-grade PO containing 260ppm water. Table 2 summarized the effects of CTAB/Zn molar ratios, reaction times, pressures and temperatures on the CO2-PO coupling reaction. When only Zn–CoIII DMCC was used as the catalyst, the TON and PC selectivity were 150 and 17.6%, respectively (entry 1 of Table 2). In another word, 82.4% of the product was poly (ether-r-carbonate) [21]. However, when only CTAB was used as the catalyst, 100% selectivity was achieved for the coupling reaction of CO2-PO with a rather low TON of 217 (entry 2, Table 2). By increasing the CTAB loading to 0.43mmol, a low TON of 512 was obtained (entry 3, Table 2). Interestingly, if 10mg Zn–CoIII DMCC was used as the main catalyst and CTAB was used as the co-catalyst, the TON (and the yield of PC) increased significantly from 1840 (18.4%) to 9934 (99.6%) when the CTAB/Zn molar ratio raised from 0.65 to 10 (entries 4–10, Table 2). It can be also seen that the increase of CTAB/Zn molar ratio from 6.28 to 10 only resulted in a slow increase of the TON. Furthermore, the TON increased from 3457 to 6373 when the reaction times were prolonged from 3h to 9h (entries 6, 11–13, Table 2). Increasing the reaction pressure from 1.0MPa to 5.0MPa could also significantly increased the TON from 4783 to 9195 when the CTAB/Zn molar ratio was fixed to be 6.28 (entries 8, 14–16, Table 2). The binary catalyst system of Zn–Co III DMCC/CTAB could efficiently catalyze the reaction in a wide range of reaction temperature from 80°C to 140°C. An increase of temperature from 80°C to 140°C resulted in a rapid increase of TON from 4749 to 9318 under 4.0MPa CO2 pressure within 7h (entries 16–19, Table 2). The productivity at 80°C was satisfied and the PC selectivity also reached 100% (entries 19–20, Table 2). At relative high temperature of 140°C, the PC selectivity still remained 100% (entry 17, Table 2), indicating that the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system could work well at such high temperature. Usually, the selectivity and productivity of some zinc-containing catalysts often decreased sharply due to the deactivation of the catalysts when the reaction temperature exceeded 120°C [36]. The experimental results indicated that the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system was efficient for the coupling reaction of PO and CO2. The cooperative catalytic effects of each component contributed to the high productivity and selectivity for the PO-CO2 coupling reaction. With the same loading of CTAB, TONs of entries 2 and 8 were 217 and 9195, respectively, which might suggested that Zn–CoIII DMCC was responsible for the high productivity. Similar phenomena were observed for the entries 3 and 10 in Table 2. On the other hand, the selectivity of all the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst systems in Table 2 remained 100% regardless of the reaction conditions. This strongly indicated that CTAB was responsible for the 100% PC selectivity. It was worthy to note that the dosage of such Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalysts used was rather low so that they could be easily dispersed in the reaction system, as evidenced by the clear resultant crude product. 3.4 The effect of water on the CO2-PO coupling reaction The water content in most of the reported catalyst systems for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides often negatively affected the catalytic activity and selectivity. To date, only few works were reported to disclose the effects of water on the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides [33,37]. In our previous work, it was found that more amounts of water in Zn–CoIII DMCC-catalyzed CO2-PO copolymerization system caused the production of more amounts of propylene carbonate (PC) via a possible “backbiting” mechanism [21]. It was hence hypothesized that Zn–CoIII DMCC might be endurable to water in CO2-PO coupling reaction system due to its unique ZnOH bond for initiating the reaction. The effects of water on CO2-PO coupling reaction catalyzed by the binary Zn–CoIII DMCC/quaternary ammonium salt catalyst were then systematically studied. As seen in Table 3 , when CaH2-dried PO with water content of 70ppm (entry 1, Table 3) was used for the coupling reaction, the PC selectivity was 100% and the TON was 9970, which was slightly higher than that of 9934 for the reaction with reagent-grade PO (260ppm water, entry 10, Table 2). When the quaternary ammonium salts with long alkyl chain (C12H25(CH3)3NBr and C10H21(CH3)3NBr, entries 2–3, Table 3) were employed as co-catalysts for the coupling reaction of CO2 with reagent-grade PO, PC selectivity still kept 100%, while TONs were slightly lower than that of entry 10 in Table 2. An industrial-grade PO with water content of 800ppm was directly tested (entry 4, Table 3), TON and PC selectivity were 9624 and 99% (1H NMR spectrum, 99.7% from GC–MS, see Figure S1), respectively. Furthermore, PO with quantitative amounts of deionized water was tested. Note that the quantitative amounts of water were achieved by adding deionized water into CaH2-dried PO by microsyringe. For the CO2-PO coupling reaction with the PO/water molar ratio of 10, the TON and PC selectivity were 8895 and 97.8%, respectively. Remarkably, even with the molar ratio of PO/water of 3 (i.e. 2.574g H2O in 24.88g PO), the TON and PC selectivity still remained high although they were clearly declined to be 7684 and 95.2% respectively. The failure for achieving 100% PC selectivity could be attributed to the generation of 1,2-propylene glycol via the reaction of water and PO (see Fig. 4 ), which was confirmed by 1H NMR and GC–MS results. Therefore, the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system was active in hydrous situations, rendering it a promising catalyst system in application. This Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system was also found to be effectively applicable for a variety of other industrial-grade terminal epoxides. As can be seen in Table 4 , the CO2 and epoxide coupling reactions were carried out for four different epoxides with water contents from 460 to 1390ppm. The 100% selectivity (1H NMR spectra, see Figure S2) and ≥99% yield were obtained for all of the reactions shown in Table 4. With this new catalyst system, hundreds of ppm water in the reaction system will no longer be the matter. 3.5 Catalyst recovery and reuse The reusability of the Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst was examined. As shown in Table 5 , the catalysts were recycled for four runs with the same reaction condition. The yield and TONs were found to be nearly the same in all cases, indicating that the Zn–CoIII DMCC catalyst was recyclable without significant loss of activity. 3.6 Proposed mechanism of the CO2-PO coupling reaction via the catalysis of Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB catalyst system Based on the above experimental results, a possible mechanism CO2-PO coupling reaction catalyzed by the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB catalyst system was proposed (Scheme 2 ). In comparison with the zinc halide salts, which is easily hydrolyzed, the ZnOH bond on the surface of Zn–CoIII DMCC (Fig. 1d) [21,24] can represent a Lewis acid site (Zn2+) associated with a Lewis base site (OH). When no CTAB was used, the ZnOH initiated the copolymerization of PO and CO2 via the routine (i) in Scheme 2 [21]. When CTAB was used, a 100% selectivity of PC production was obtained because of a much stronger nucleophilicity of Br−. On the basis of the previous reports [18,19,38,39], the synergistic effects between acidic site (Zn) and basic site (Br− in CTAB) was shown in the routine (ii) (Scheme 2). Firstly, the PO monomer was coordinated with the Lewis acid site Zn and the Br− anion of CTAB then made a nucleophilic attack on the less hindered carbon atom of the active PO to afford its ring-opening, generating intermediate 1; Secondly, CO2 was inserted into the zinc-alkoxide intermediate 1, producing the intermediate anion 2. Finally, PC was produced by an intramolecular cyclic elimination. The acid site and quaternary ammonium salt were regenerated. The 100% PC selectivity was observed in the presence of CTAB, indicating that PO-CO2 copolymerization was completely inhibited. These results might be explained by the interaction of intermediate anions (1 or 2) and quaternary ammonium cations, which prevented the intermediate anions 1 or 2 from attacking new coordinated PO to afford polymer chain. Furthermore, due to the strong electron-withdrawing ability of terminal Br, the adjacent methylene carbon would be more electron-positive. As a result, the intramolecular cyclic elimination would be produced more easily. 4 Conclusions The nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC in conjunction with quaternary ammonium salts were highly active and selective binary catalyst systems for the coupling reaction between CO2 and hydrous epoxides. These nanoporous Zn–CoIII DMCC/quaternary ammonium salt binary catalyst systems were tolerant to water and suitable for various epoxides with solvent-free procedures. These unparalleled characteristics rendered such catalyst systems promising applications for the chemical fixation of CO2. coredata.dc:description: Although most of the zinc-containing catalysts show excellent catalytic activity for the coupling reaction of carbon dioxide (CO2) with epoxides, generally, trace amounts of water in the reaction systems could cause a significant decrease of the catalytic activity. In this work, a nanoporous zinc-cobalt double metal cyanide complex (Zn–CoIII DMCC) with high surface area was synthesized via a modified hydrothermal process using tri-block copolymer EO20PO70EO20 (P123) as the template. When cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was used as the co-catalyst, the Zn–CoIII DMCC/CTAB binary catalyst system could effectively catalyze the coupling reaction of CO2 with hydrous propylene oxide (PO), producing propylene carbonate (PC) with nearly 100% productivity and 100% selectivity. This binary catalyst system could also catalyze the coupling reaction of other commercial epoxides and CO2 without using any solvents with nearly 100% productivity and 100% selectivity. With such new catalyst system, hundreds of ppm water in the reaction system will no longer be the matter.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active and selective binary catalyst system for the coupling reaction of CO2 and hydrous epoxides
